This is a beautiful example of how something that seems random and is, for all practical purposes, considered to be random, like the exact shape of a snowflake, is in fact not random at all, but the product of the incredibly specific circumstances at the exact place and time that it happened. So much so, that it happens six times over in the exact same way, and under carefully controlled conditions, can be replicated almost exactly. It really makes me think what other "random" things are just caused by small differences in circumstances that we can't see.

Growing up in So Cal I didn't see much snow as a kid, but now I'm up in Oregon and I too take pix of snowflakes. These custom, lab grown designer flakes are certainly beautiful, but wild ones don't necessarily grow like that. Temperature and moisture fluctuations can be so minute that different sides of the same flake can grow differently. And they usually aren't flat, they touch each other and grow from each other and influence each other. Sometimes they get huge! But, lab grown or wild, they are endlessly fascinating.

This all applies closely to the way mineral crystals grow. Every mineral has a characteristic composition and one or more characteristic crystal habits – patterns of crystal growth related to temperatures, pressures, chemical environment, moisture content, movement, distortion, as well as other factors.

Libbrecht's snowflakes grow freely in the air under exactly controlled conditions. Mineral crystals that form within the Earth under changing conditions and they typically collide with each other and with various impurities which greatly complicates what happens, yet the basic principles are the same. Because of this, geologists (mineralogists, petrologists) can examine rock samples (igneous and metamorphic rocks) and determine fairly accurately what the history of the minerals and the rock that contains them might have been. Much of this has been confirmed by observing volcanic rocks forming and then examining them, as well as by working with rock samples or molten material in the laboratory to artificially reproduce rocks that are found in Nature.

Rock-forming minerals and other minerals never grow in an undisturbed environment, so none of them ever grow absolutely "perfectly." The closest that naturally forming minerals might approach this is when individual crystals or loose crystal structures grow in some sort of cavity within some rock structure and produce samples that are very highly valued by mineral collectors who might pay hundreds or many thousands of dollars for a unique sample. Snowflakes, on the other hand, beautiful though they might be, are very difficult to collect, let alone preserve, display and admire for very long.

By the way, ice/snow/water is a mineral – the most common mineral on the surface of Earth.

Understanding the formation of snowflakes - their shape and size - has a lot of practical applications. But, but, but.... it's made of hydrogen plasma? In plasma state, without ever changing its phase throughout the sun?

I simply cannot agree with the sentence "there are no identical snowflakes". Just think about the monkey and typewriter theory. Giving enough time, it's impossible to not form 2 perfectly identical snowflakes.
As this man said, as no twins are identical, just similar in some way, not a pair of snowflakes are identical, just similar in some way. But let's think about it: how many snowflakes he seen in his entire life, and how many flakes have been formed naturally just in that time on the Earth? And how many were formed before he has born? And how many flakes will be after him? These are huge numbers, which cannot be observed and catalogized.
Only in one snowball you can find around 22.400 snowflakes, which (let's say) is around one year of work of this scientist. Working 40 years, he can observe enough snowflake for around 40 snowballs. In his entire life (work)!
In a cubic foot of snow are approximately 1 billion snowflakes. How many cubic foot of snow you wipe off your car in just one season? How many cars there are in your city? And we are still talking about a negligible part of formed snowflakes in only a short period of your life.
So, because his affirmation is based on a very tiny amount of observed snowflakes, i just simply cannot believe there are no identical snowflakes.

Nice. This is Diffusion Limited Aggregation (DLA) pattern formation. It was first demonstrated in the first successful computer simulations run by Prof. Len Sander (and a student assistent, Dr. Nancy Hecker) at the University of Michigan's Dept. of Physics in the 1900's. Reproducing and varying these snowflake (and eg metal crystal formation at electrodes, etc.) in the computer simulation showed that the simple DLA algorithim had captured the essential physics. I don't want to take anything away from it, but in the spirit of science, I have to point out a comment that stuck out as 'wild' and unsupported IMO, and that's how "we get from the quantum mechanics that governs a water molecule, to a hexagonal prism of ice." It seems like you pulled out QM out of a magicians hat. This snowflake formation could be very well explained by classical physics. In fact, water is often simulated using classical models; quantum models are just too computationally demanding. I don't think we can simulate enough water, long enough to unravel its secreted quantum mechanically, but classical mechanics brings us tantalisingly close. Yet, we can't seem to be able to lower a water simulation temperature until low density ice is spontaneously formed. It should be feasible, but so far it seems impossible to freeze water from the condensed phase, not the supersaturated phase. The greatest secrete water holds is how it turns into ice in a simulation.  We do not need to go at the electron level too understand water, just how it bounces around at the molecular level should be enough, but it isn't. I think you should explore the greatest, simplest unknown mystery of the world: Not how water forms snowflakes but how water supercools and makes ice.

The idea of "nucleation barriers" can be generalized to crystal growth of any matter. That's why so many minerals exibit different crystal morphology and/or habitus, despite having the same chemical composition, i.e. the same chemical formula (think of diamond and graphite, for example). These are known as polymorphs. The nucleation barrier arise from Gibbs free energy of nucleation, which has to have a negative change in order for nucleation to happen spontaneously, and that is obviously tied to pressure and temperature of the system, but also to the presence of small impurities (particles) in the otherwise homogeneous solution, which serve as a starting point for nucleation to happen. After the formation of a nucleus, crystal growth is controled by the geometry of chemical bonds, which in turn control the growth of crystal faces. Crystal faces with more "broken chemical bonds" (i.e. crystal faces with larger surface energy) grow quicker, as those are the faces molecules from the solution will preferably choose to bond with in order to minimize the surface energy. Exposed crystal surfaces on a crystal therefore have the lowest surface energies, as those surfaces with higher energies have been "overgrown" so to speak. That is the path for a crystal to reach its thermodynamical equlibrium (which is usually not true equlibrium but the kinetics of crystal growth are usually so slow those crystal can exist in a metastable phase for a long periods of time). That's why the morphology of a crystal can tell us a lot about the conditions at which a crystal has formed, and even those minerals that are otherwise unstable at the surface of the Earth can still persist, even though they formed at a vastly different conditions, such as those in the Earth's lower crust or mantle.

Really picky point, but the initial "U" in "Ukichiro" (宇吉郎／うきちろう)is not pronounced "you", and the "ch" is not pronounced "h".

Japanese 「う」, which is Latinized to "u" is always just the vowel you hear and say in English "boot", without any initial voiced palatal approximant, except when following certain other vowels. (Sort-of. In some dialects it can turn into something like an English short "i", but that isn't relevant here.) It is never "yu".

Japanese 「ち」, Latinized to "chi" when it does not precede a subscript 「や」(ya) group sound, always starts a "ch" sound. (Sort-of. It is not exactly ch, but it is definitely not h. Lingual, not glottal. Stop sound produced at the tip of the tongue, not fricative produced at mid-tongue or base.)

宇: う: u ("oo", not "you", but not stretched out)
吉: きち: kichi ("keechee", not "keehee", but not stretched out)
郎: ろう: rō ("row", stretched out, う picking up the preceding お)

This is slightly ironic, because the usual Kanji for snow (雪) has "yuki" (ゆき) as a normal pronunciation. However, it would be rare to see it in a male name. Female name, sure, but not male. You could force it, as in 「雪浩」 ("Yukihiro", note that the final vowel is not stretched) or something, but Yukihiro would far more likely be 「幸浩」 or 「之宏」 or something like that.

This work has much broader practical applications than he talked about. The most common method of purifying compounds after synthesis or extraction is called 'recrystallization'. Finding a solvent mix and temperature range to do that can be tricky, particularly for organic molecules with complex shapes. If the crystals grow too needle-like or too plate-like they clog up the container and trap solvents and byproducts, so it's important to find an intermediate range of saturation and temperature so they can be purified.

Love this episode, especially his enthusiasm when he shows the fit of the model and the experiment. I can relate a lot, because what he does with snowflakes I do with rocks and minerals. By looking at their shape, composition, etc. and comparing natural samples with experiments it's possible to figure out the conditions during mineral growth and hence reconstruct the path of rocks through the crust of the Earth. Doing science is often hard and frustrating and nothing pays off more than the excitement you feel when a result matches your hypothesis.
I also get the "but why" question a lot. It's easy to come up with some kind of 'useful' application, but if I'd answer honestly - I simply want to understand why stuff (i.e. rocks) looks the way it does :)

Dr. Libbrecht's explanation for snowflake formation is impressive but the explanation given in this video about what exactly causes every snowflake to be different from every other snowflake is scientific nonsense. "Each snowflake takes a unique path, and therefore they experience a unique set of conditions, which is why no two snowflakes are alike." Really? The reality is that during any measurable snow event within a particular geographical region the snowflakes involved certainly take a different path to the ground but to conclude that within those varying paths there are enough atmospheric differences to account for the difference in shape of every snowflake is the result of dishonest and/or bad science. You can certainly create unique conditions for a particular snowflake in a laboratory setting by turning some knobs or pressing some buttons, as was demonstrated in this video, but in the natural world hundreds of thousands of unformed snowflakes, some only millimeters apart, each falling out of the atmosphere at the same velocity, in the same geographical vicinity, are certainly not passing through the hundreds of thousands of different atmospheric conditions before they reach the ground. You would need a an innumerable number of atmospheric differences just to account for every snowflake in even the smallest of snow events. Impossible. Therefore, the explanation you have put forth in this video should be completely rejected and a more realistic explanation for this phenomenon should be explored.

There is a big reason why Dr. Libbrecht and so many other "experts" are unable to provide a plausible explanation for this phenomenon. Dr. Libbrecht has started with a faulty assumption. Dr. Libbrecht stated that snowflake shapes... "appear spontaneously" and that "There is no blueprint for what's going on." Since this assumption is incorrect, the conclusion is incorrect. Dr. Libbrecht has rejected the correct assumption and therefore must resort to presenting a mere guess as a fact in an effort to appear like he knows the answer. A faulty assumption leads to a faulty conclusion. Allow me to share the true explanation for the amazing phenomenon of snowflake shape differences. It's quite simple really. God, who is the infinite Creator of the universe is the explanation. We will never be able to explain the cause of snowflake shape differences using finite human wisdom alone. The fact that no two snowflakes are ever alike only reinforces what God told us thousands of years ago about how He has revealed His existence to us through the many amazing wonders of the universe. Read Isaiah 40:26, Psalms 19:1, Romans 1:20 if you doubt this to be true. Mr. Bently, who by the way, was mostly homeschooled and a firm believer in a God created universe, knew this about God and was able to show the world one of these many wonders in1885 using nothing more than a snowflake under a microscope, which he referred to as a "...a masterpiece of design." It's a beautiful thing when a scientist trying to make discoveries about the wonders of the natural world starts with the correct assumptions.

Scientists like Dr. Libbrecht, need to take a page or two out of Mr. Bently's book when it comes to science and the assumptions necessary for reaching the right conclusions about the natural world. Better yet, picking up a Bible and reading it would be even better. More scientists need to read the Bible today. Not only would their science be better but more importantly they would find out how much they and everyone else in the world needs Jesus Christ.

About practical usage of that: This research is actually extremely useful in leading industries, such as electronics, biology, material science
And no, I am not talking about making processors or building from snowflakes))
The thing is that this is very good example about interaction between quantum mechanics and "classical" one as well as, for example, answering on a question why ice is slippery. Currently some way or another almost every industry should be able to work on a quantum scale: biology(reading DNA, learning about how viruses works and so on), electronics(struggling to make 2nm transistors and smaller), creating new materials(like graphene, carbon fiber) - all of that are going to be much easier if researchers can intuitively understand how quantum mechanics laws can influence something on a bigger scale. And such examples like this video is actually very good booster for that. So professor's work actually have much more practically useful knowledge, than most of people can imagine on a first glance.

I have observed moisture frozen on refrigeration pipes since like 1993. Thee is definitely a difference in the "ice" forming on the cold pipes if the temperature is -5°C or -30°C. I love Ve and all the cool stuff that's discussed, but as a Japanese speaker I cringe whenever a Japanese word or name is butchered. So allow me to offer this quick Japanese lesson.

Ukichiro [oo-key-chee-row], that's oo, as in moo (the sound a cow makes), key (which opens a lock), chee, as in Pee Chee (the school folders from the 80's), row, as in "Row, row, row the boat, gently down the stream..." (This will get you 80% correct, as the 'r' actually is a hard r that is more like combining an 'r' with a 'd').

Nakaya [naw-kaw-yaw], that's naw, as in singing: "Na-na-na-na, Na-na-na-na, hey, hey, hey, goodbye.", kaw, as in the voice of a crow, and yaw as in yawn minus the 'wn'.

Arigato! (Thanks!), as in "Domo arigato, Mr. Roboto."

All you have...everything...here in this episode is related to growth, not nucleation. You may want to look up stable growth versus unstable growth; dendritic and cellular growth versus planar growth. These concepts have been very well understood in materials science for at least half a century, if not more. While I agree with him that "what's the point of this" is a destructive question, that we should foster curiosity-inspired research, etc, I also think that there is more utility to this than is obvious.

Nucleation and denitrification are really important - a big part of why lithium-ion batteries die over time is that ions landing on the anode form dendrites, which accumulate and reduce battery capacity or can catastrophically create a sort of short circuit inside the battery. If we could get that process to form smooth, flat surfaces, we might be able to vastly extend the lifespan of lithium-ion batteries which could be a major boon for things like electric cars and grid-level energy storage (arguably the real roadblock to wind and solar power generation).

I don't necessarily know whether or not this particular research will help with that, but it is certainly a conversation happening in the same room.

Well beyond just figuring out snowflakes, I would assume the models of ice crystal growth advance our knowledge in general crystalline structure growth.  Water just happens to be a very workable material to form experimental observations on (it doesn’t require tons of time, pressure, heat, exotic chemicals, etc).  And really advances in understanding crystals leads to better engineered materials, it also helps to understand how very simple forces, with little input/information/intervention, can be manipulated to produce complex highly organized output materials (re: wolfram’s cellular automata)

I’m very slightly concerned with the statement: No two snow flakes are alike (meaning “the same”). The bond angles and bond length between Hydrogen atoms and Oxygen in water are nearly infinite. However, because of the available locations for Hydrogens to bond to Oxygen there are limits to what the eventual snow flake can be.
Considering ALL of the snow flakes that have EVER fallen on Earth, it seems like there is some possibility that two of them have been “alike” - that is to say “the same.”
The statement (no two alike) was seen as a silly question in the video. However, there are physical, chemical, electro static, and structural constrains on water molecules that limit the shapes of snowflakes to less than infinite. And that’s not considering quantum effects.

Yes, trees being complex  is understandable, but the snowflake system would seem to have only two changing parameters:  temperature, and time.  Hence,  changes in just two parameters interacting can constitute a complex system.  In the Mandelbrot set , changes in just two parameters gives complexity.

For a water molecule to freeze onto a surface, the vibrational energy (heat) of fusion needs to immediately move away from the crystallization site, or the molecule will bounce off.  Regions in a crystal that effectively remove heat are where crystallization happens fastest.  A snowflake is a heat sink.  Another reason for snowflake symmetry is because if one side were to grow really fast that side gets warmer and this would cause molecules to bounce off rather than attaching to the surface. 惠子谓庄子曰：吾有大树，人谓之樗，其大本拥肿而不中绳墨，其小枝卷曲而不中规矩，立之涂，匠者不顾，今子之言，大而无用，众所同去也。
惠子说：我家里有棵大树。我们也可以想像，庄子这篇文章，写的像是他谈话的一个记事剧本。庄子跟惠子素来是好朋友，又是抬杠的好对手，碰面就抬杠。惠子说到自己家里的一个瓜太大了，无用；庄子就说，你这个家伙有大瓜不晓得用，你真是个大傻瓜，所以你的头脑不清，草包一个。

惠子挨了他的骂，没有生气，倒转来又骂庄子说：“我告诉你啊！我还不止有那个大傻瓜呢！我家里还有棵大树，这棵树叫樗。”这种树是杂木，南方都有，福建很多，比榕树还容易种，福州就多榕树，因为榕树很容易种，随便都会长大的。惠子说：这棵樗树很大，“其大本拥肿”，它的根根臃肿松软，“不中绳墨”。

绳墨是什么呢？几十年前木工用的古代的规矩，就是标准。现在做木工的不用了，过去做木工的用一条绳线，一个墨斗，把一条黑绳线从墨斗拉出来，当作尺子测好，用指头拉线，这么一弹，画成笔直黑线，那个就叫绳墨。规矩是圆规方矩。惠子在这里说他家一棵大树，树根树枝弯弯曲曲的，也不能用墨绳去量。换言之，怎样量都不合规矩。所以这棵树长在路旁，“匠者不顾”，无论木材店的大老板，或是木工，看都不看。而且这种杂木，味道又不好闻，所以人家都不要。这个惠子骂人，也是不带脏字，因为他挨了庄子的骂，他也转骂过来。他又说：老兄啊！你的话“大而无用”，你啊！也光吹大牛，同那棵树一样，“众所同去”。我看你啊！讨厌得、臭得也同那棵树一样，谁看到你，头都要歪一歪走掉的。两个人就这样对骂。

庄子曰：子独不见狸牲乎，卑身而伏，以候敖者；东西跳梁，不辟高下；中于机辟，死于罔罟。
“子独不见狸狌乎”，庄子说，这有什么稀奇啊！你有没有看到过小狐狸呀！狌是狌，狸是狸，两种动物同狐狸差不多。我们普通在南方看到的，多半是狌，不是真正的狐狸，算是假狐狸。独另有个名字叫野干，所以研究庄子很麻烦，植物动物标本都要看，我们现在只讲道理，不讲那个文字。他说这两种动物是有名的狡猾，为什么说狸狌而不提出来狼狗呢？狸狌这个动物多疑，性情狐疑不定。一个人多心病，头脑多猜疑，就是狐狸个性，所以文学上形容为狐疑，狐疑不定。狐狸狡猾又多疑，“卑身而伏”，它走起路来，矮矮的，偷偷的，慢慢的过来，人都看不见。它以为自己聪明，做了的事情，讲了的话，以为别人不知道，结果啊！“以候敖者”，高明打猎的人，都晓得它的毛病，利用它的弱点，把它给捉住了。狸狌、狐狸这些东西，自己玩它的小聪明，有时候它也觉得自己很伟大。“东西跳梁，不辟高下”，在树上跳过来跳过去，屋顶上跳过来跳过去，它觉得自己也跳得很高啊，也很有本事，也不怕，以为没有人看见。结果人当然看得见，人聪明，把机关埋伏在那里，等它一跳，“咚”掉进去了。“中于机辟，死于罔罟”，结果捉它的机关，捕它的网，都布置好了，最后还是被人捉去。

庄子都没有骂脏字，但他就是当面骂惠子，你这个家伙，就像狐狸一样，就像小猴子一样，你以为你有什么了不起？庄子就是这样骂，不像我们骂得很笨蛋，一定很难听，最后说不定打起来了。而庄子与惠子两个人，一边喝酒一边谈着，一边对骂，好像蛮舒服的样子。

This sentence, "... supersaturated; meaning there are more water molecules in the air than there would be in equilibrium at this temperature," isn't reduced to a simple state. This type of study: I want to know how a specific thing works. I had the same drive to understand how naval armor worked so that I could put REAL results into miniature naval wargames that I played while in college and after. I had no idea what a hole I was stepping into since it turned out that NOBODY had worked this out EVER (even when battleships were the main protection of the nations using them; no joke) for the main heavy armor type used in battleship[s from the early 1890s until they were considered obsolete as the most important warships from about the middle pf WWII (aircraft carriers and submarines took over rather rapidly). So, while I had a lot of information about the softer kinds of armor used in such things as decks and turret roof and in thin armor of smaller warships, the thick face-hardened ("Krupp Cemented" face-hardened nickel-chromium steel armor introduced in 1894 and quickly taking over the side armor of battleships during the rest of the 1890s and thereafter) was usually just handled by "fudge factors" grafted onto the somewhat accurate formulae for the softer armors.(by the end pf WWII the US Navy had developed extremely good and reasonably accurate formulae and data sets for softer armor types, for example). So I discovered that I had to create my own formulae and data sets to handle the rather different properties of face-hardened naval armor that could be over two feet thick (turret frontal armor on the Japanese super-battleships of the YAMATO Class in WWII) (!!!). I was very systematic and tried to separate out each different property of the KC armor, several of which simply did not exist in the soft armor, such as how thick and hard the face of the armor was.

I spent over 50 years on this study and was amazingly lucky in getting sources of information (my luck was beyond belief, as I see it). I succeeded beyond my wildest dreams. In the process, I discovered various rules that changed things from those prior "rules-of-thumb" used to fudge the soft armor information to get something that "kin-of" worked -- "Good enough for Government work" literally applied to warship design plans. For example, I discovered by chance -- by matching test result plots to my created formulae that could calculate those plots -- that scaling (how armor resistance changed just by making the size of the projectiles and plates bigger or smaller with nothing else changed) varied directly with face-thickness percentage when the effects and numbers in the formulae representing these thickness percentages were graphed on a LOG-LOG graph paper scale. In fact, I was not the one who noticed this but a mathematician friend who was reviewing my various results. To get a straight line on LOG-LOG paper plotting systems is highly unusual, but my formulae did it by simply matching the test results to the formulae I had created. I am still not completely in understanding of the seeming physical law I seem to have found, but it works, so I must have done something right!

Why study snowflakes? Because water isn't the only thing that freezes. When you grow monocrystalline silicon, it's essentially freezing. When you cast metals in a foundry, it is said to "freeze" when it cools and hardens back into a solid. In other words, lots of things crystalize when they move from the liquid (or solution) into the solid-state.

Figured out? People have known how snowflakes work for over a century! Water crystals have hexagonal symmetry. The shape of a snowflake is simply a record of changes in its environment as it gets blown around in the air, repeated 6 times.

Very interesting video as always! Lovely content. There is one aspect that wasn't discussed though that some may find interesting, and that is the role of the the structure of interfacial water. As water at interfaces are less ordered, it has some liquid properties (Book: Molecular Driving Forces 2nd Ed, Ken Dill and Sarina Bromberg, publisher: Garland Science, page 615).
This is especially true at ice-solid interfaces, which is one of the explanations why we can ice skate (DOI:10.1039/C6CP05303C). Thus, I am thinking this could also have a role at the water-air interface in the formation of snowflakes, as the molecular motions at this interphase also should change around the temperature interval displayed in the video.

When people were watching birds nobody thought it would ever be useful. And then the bird flue hit and everybody wanted to know migration patterns of the various species. There's a beautiful metaphor here for how we think about humanity and the way that our conception of what is "real" is affected by what you see represented. We're used to thinking of snowflakes as only those hexagonal fractal-ish shapes, but in reality we can't understand the underlying physics of their formation until we consider the full range of shapes they can have. Without that we aren't even able to recognize the most interesting questions to ask. Something similar is going on when folks reduce humanity to cartoons like "there's only two genders, XY and XX." That seems real only because of what images of us we choose to focus on. (Yes, I recognize I'm saying that humanity is made up of special snowflakes...)

Knowledge is a worthy end goal full stop. Having said that, if you're asking what applications this has then you need to look around. micro-engineering, producing the next CPU's with insane transistor density, anything involving deposition as a means of manufacturing this directly applies to. Beyond that, this is a study on boundary/transition phases, which is also extremely important in almost any application where phase transitions are occurring (news flash, that's everywhere on earth). Ultimately I would argue any physics research you do on earth is directly applicable to us because by it's nature it is likely to apply to other things on earth. We are carbon and water flesh bags, as are most other living things on this planet, any physics related to any of the common elements, molecules, proteins, etc. that make up living organisms is immediately important with vast applications/results.

As fun as this is, there are also practical applications to Dr. Libbrecht's work.  Specifically, within the context of winter sliding sports, the coefficient of friction between track and running surface (i.e. ski base) is heavily influenced by the crystal structure of the snow.  Wax companies tend to sell their products with temperature ranges as an easy-to-follow guideline, but at an elite racing level, wax and equipment selection are much more heavily driven by classifying the track conditions into (admittedly, much broader, qualitative) snow types.  Of course, this changes over time - freeze/thaw cycles, compaction from it's own weight, various grooming techniques, traffic from skiers themselves, and many other environmental factors will all have effects on both the surface of the track and the macro structure of the layers underneath - but ultimately, at least for a few days or until a major thaw, the macro snow type will still be a function of the crystalline structure of the individual flakes when they first fell.

Signs of Allah in Snowflakes

Anyone who takes a close look at snowflakes can see that they come in a variety of shapes. It is estimated that a single cubic meter of snow holds about 350 million snowflakes! These flakes are all hexagonal and have crystal-like structures. However, each one of them possesses a unique shape. For years, scientists have been searching for answers to such questions as how these shapes ever came about, how it is that each one of them has a different shape and what provides their symmetry. Every bit of information that is gained reveals another magnificent mastery present in the snowflakes. The variety and perfection of the hexagonal structure of snowflakes is a manifestation of Allah's status as the Originator (al-Badi). Allah is the One Who made good everything that He has created. The formation of snowflakes constitutes yet another aspect of Allah's endless artistry.

These thin, small flakes look like multi-pointed stars or tiny needle heads. The formation of the snowflakes in the pictures is truly amazing. For years, the orderly structure of snowflakes has caught people's attention. Since 1945, research has been carried out in a quest to discover which factors give the final shape to the crystals. A single snowflake is a pile of crystals consisting of more than 200 ice crystals. Snowflakes are made up of water molecules that are shaped in a perfect order. Snowflakes, one of nature's true architectural wonders, are shaped when water vapor gets cold while passing through clouds. This takes place like so:

Passing through the clouds, water molecules scattered everywhere in a disorganized way throughout water vapor begin to lose their random movement due to the fall in temperature. After a while, the water molecules, moving more slowly, begin to form groups and consequently become solid. Yet, there is no disorder whatsoever in their groupings. On the contrary, they always unite as microscopic hexagonal forms that look similar to each other. Each snowflake at first consists of a single hexagonal water molecule, then other hexagonal water molecules come and attach to this first piece. According to experts on the subject, the basic factor that determines the shape of a snowflake is that these hexagonal water molecules are joined together just like links in a chain. In addition, the pieces of crystals, which normally should look alike, take on very different shapes according to the temperature and level of moisture.(1)

Why is it that there is a hexagonal symmetry in all snowflakes and why is each of them different from the others? Why are their edges angled rather then straight? Scientists are still trying to find answers to these questions. Yet, this much is evident: Allah is the One Who has no partners in creation, is the Possessor of an endless power and the Originator of everything.

_____________________________________

1- Roger Davey, David Stanley, "All about ice," New Scientist, September 6, 1993.

8:19 Isn't it the prism facet growing to create a column rather than the basal facet? The basal facet growing is what gives a flat snowflake. 14:01 Again, it's the basal facet growing outward in all directions that makes the flat snowflake. The prism facets are only stretching horizontally to match the growth of the basal facet but the prism facet itself is not growing vertically to create a column. 15:19 and here is where you reverse to the truth that it's a narrow prism that forms a plate rather than a growing one. Growing prism facets make columns while growing basal facets make plates.

I think the "why" question at the end is always a stupid one when it comes to science, whether it's Saturn's rings, how snowflakes form, or anything else. The key thing about all science is that we never know how useful any knowledge might be until we actually acquire it and scientists and engineers can then find uses for it. Understanding exactly how iron, carbon and other atoms interact to form different crystal structures in steel has allowed us to find new steel alloys with specific properties or to engineer better ways to make existing steels that improve consistency or reduce cost. Understanding exactly how snowflakes form might seem useless, but who knows what we might be able to do with that knowledge in the future? Research is never wasted if knowledge and understanding is gained, because understanding one part of our universe will always help us understand others too.
This could also mean that -4 and -14 is a yet not discovered superposition/resonance pattern that matches a specific crystal growth with water as the addition material.

It would be interesting to create an algorithm that can generate a field of snowflake shapes on a 2d plane with temperature on the x axis and humidity on the y axis which matches the Nakaya diagram.

It’s like the compact higher dimensions in a string theory spacetime but instead it’s snowflakes and phase space.

This can be done approximately with a GAN algorithm that trains on a database of snowflakes images matched with humidity and temperature values, but a precise physical simulation algorithm would really be the icing on the cake.

In fact a metric to measure the deviation between the images in the snowflake GAN’s latent space and the images of the shapes from the snowflake simulation’s phase space would be a good method how to measure the accuracy of the snowflake simulation algorithm.

And actually there could be a GAN that generates code that would result in snowflakes simulations and the generation of the code can be guided by minimizing the aforementioned metric.

Although this guy clearly knows more than almost any other human on the planet about snowflakes, I'm not sure how he (or others) came to the conclusion that no 2 snowflakes are exactly the same. It seems to me that the opposite must be true, as in total on the earth there has to have been an ungodly amount of total flakes formed over the life of the planet, so many that it would be statistically impossible to not have 2 identical snowflakes at some point in time, or for that matter, at many points in time. There can be like 20 trillion to 20 quadrillion snowflakes in a single snow storm, and many snow storms are all over the globe at any given time, constantly melting and then more are formed, over and over and over, year after year, decade after decade, etc,etc. No matter how complex, I don't see how many wouldn't end up the same (or at least a single pair), same with grains of sand. It seems similar to the statement that in the entire universe no 2 planets would ever be the same. (Which would also have to be incorrect)

I’m 33yrs old currently. I didn’t realize snow flakes were a real “thing” that happens/exists until I was about 25. I thought it was something made up by Hollywood for movies and TV. Granted I’m a Southern California native but I have experienced snowfall before. I remember the first “camera ready” snowflake I saw with my own eyes, a beautiful six-sided stereotypical snowflake that fell onto my jacket and I nearly lost my mind. I felt like such an idiot for running around to my friends like I had just won the lottery only for them to look at me stone-faced like “yeah… are you high?”. I guess it’s all perspective though. I live in the Mojave desert of CA, I had a friend visiting me from the East coast and he couldn’t believe tumbleweeds really tumbled over and across the road like in the movies. All I said was “yeah and they’re a pain in the neck to avoid while driving when the winds pick up!”

• Consider Silicon Dioxide crystals being grown in a plasma deposition furnace. If you use a speck cut crystal to act as the kernel, could you vary the perameters (heat, silicon/oxygen densities, etc.) to build a block of semiconducting material with conducting filaments? • How about using Carbon to make something porous like aerogel, but with the strength of diamond?
• Or making massive sheets of Graphene entire meters across?
• Or growing ceramic structures over Carbon Nanotubes?
• Hell, even using deposition techniques to create alternating laminated Polymers over Carbon Fibre lattices?
Imagine the possibilitıes for new materials: building massive windows of perfect clarity, as thin as a soap bubble, yet as strong as steel. A perfectly straight 10 mm tube of composite material that stretches out for 100 metres, but that's so light you could lift it with one hand & hold it horizontally without any sag...

The claim about conditions determining the symmetry of the complex crystals is just a hypothesis that needs to be proven by deliberately creating a microclimate that allows an asymmetrical snowflake to be reliably formed with the level of control that a symmetrical one can.  Until that is done the alternative hypothesis that there is an electron resonance distributed across the entire crystal is just as valid, in fact both may be operating at the same time in which case good luck designing an experiment to separate the influence of each. To be clear when I say asymetrical I do not mean with one side less developed I mean developed with different a branching sequence. Imagine it as if you took two flakes and cut them in half and joined the different parts.🤓❄
